attributes.title: The Effect of Masculine Honor Beliefs on Expectations for Bullying Victims
attributes.description: Experiences of bullying have been found to contribute to adulthood anxiety and depression (Roth, Coles, & Heimberg, 2002) and increased self-harm, violent behavior, and psychotic symptoms in adolescence (Arseneault & Shakoor, 2010). Despite the unfortunate effects of bullying, many adults may hold expectations about how bullying victims should respond to this injustice, especially if the victim is a male. Masculine honor is an ideology in which men are expected to respond with aggression to threats or insults against themselves, family, or property (Cohen, 1998). We contend that masculine honor beliefs may help explain perceptions of bullies as well as possible expectations for bullying victims in responding to the bully. As our lab has previously shown, we expect that male victims will be expected to confront their bully violently, while female victims will not be expected to violently confront their bully. We expect that masculine honor beliefs will be associated with more negative perceptions of the bully, and the victim, unless the victim defends themselves violently rather than ignoring the threat or deferring the problem to a teacher or parent (especially young boys compared to girls) (O’Dea, Chalman, Castro Bueno, & Saucier, 2018; O’Dea, Martens, & Saucier, 2019).

q2.value:
We contend that masculine honor beliefs may help explain perceptions of bullies as well as possible expectations for bullying victims in responding to the bully. Based on previous research, we expect that male victims will be expected to confront their bully at a higher level than female victims. We expect that higher endorsement of masculine honor will be associated will greater expectations that the victim confront the bully. Further, we expect an interaction between masculine honor beliefs and bully victim sex such that masculine honor beliefs will always be associated with a greater expectation for confrontation but that this expectation will be stronger for boys than girls. 
We also expect that masculine honor beliefs will be associated with more negative perceptions of the bully due to expectations that one should engage positively with their community.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: The research will be conducted online and there will be no interaction between the researchers and participants.

question.value: 2(bullying gender: male, female) X Continuous (Masculine Honor Beliefs) Between groups design

q7.value: The masculine honor beliefs scale will be counter-balanced with the rest of the survey. The dependent variables will be presented in a random order. The items in each scale will be presented in a random order.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Adults over the age of eighteen will be recruited through Amazon’s CloudPrime software to complete a survey on Qualtrics. They will read a short story either about a male or female victim and their bully, in which the victim is threatened by a bully. The participants will then complete a number of survey items how they feel the victim should respond to the bully as well as the masculine honor beliefs scale (which will be counter-balanced with the rest of the survey). The items will assess how responsible the participants feel the victim is for defending himself or herself in a violent or non-violent manner. Afterward, participants will complete items on the likability of the bully and the victim.

q11.value: We need a total of 179 participants, however we will be collecting a total of 300 participants to allow for participants who fail attention check to be removed from the data set without compromising our study.

q12.value: The necessary budget for this project is $375. Money will be used to recruit participants through Amazon’s CloudPrime software and pay 25% fees to use CloudPrime. We will need a total of 179 participants according to power analyses where F2= .0625 (medium effect size) with power = .80 and alpha = .05 with 3 tested predictors. However we predict we will need to collect 300 participants to account for potential failed attention checks that are common using online recruiting software. Each participant will receive $1 for their participation.

question.value:
Participants responses to each of the following scales will be combined by averaging their scores into an overarching composite score: 
masculine honor belief scale
bully likability 
victim likability
physical confrontation expectation
verbal confrontation expectation
alerting parents
alerting teachers
no response

We will use Jamovi software to conduct a series of 2(bullying gender: male, female) X Continuous (Masculine Honor Beliefs) linear regressions. Each dependent variable will be tested in a separate analysis. Our dependent variables are bully likability, victim likability, physical confrontation expectation, verbal confrontation expectation, alerting parents, alerting teachers, no response.

q19.value:
We will use NHST with an alpha level of .05 to make inferences based on our pre-registered meaningful effect of F^= .0265. 
We are conducting multiple tests using multiple dependent variables. 
However, we will not make corrections to account for familywise error rate because we predict all of the outcome variables to support our hypotheses and will not make generalized conclusions based on the presence of one or two significant effects.

q20.value: Participants will be unable to advance in the study if they fail one of two captchas. We will also exclude participants who fail any of seven attention checks throughout the survey. See attached survey.

q21.value: Participants will be included in analyses for which they have full data.

name.value: COVID-19, Xenophobia and Travel Ban Experiment

other.value:
We may examine if PVD subscales interact with virus prime vs control conditions to predict xenophobia. 

Exploratory DVS
Likelihood of Wearing a Mask: For the following statement please report how much either agree or disagree with the following statements (0 Strongly Agree-100 Strongly Agree). 
1. I would wear a face mask in public to ensure that I would not get sick 
2. I would wear a facemask in public IF I was sick

sample.value: For an effect size f = .2 and 80% power, a total sample of 246 is needed across all three condition. We plan to recruit 450 participants (150 per condition) to exceed 80% power. On MTurk, we will run 500 participants in anticipation of excluding participants who fail the attention checks.

analyses.value:
A one-way ANOVA with three conditions will be conducted to assess if those who in the virus condition have higher scores on the Fear Based Xenophobia Scale. We predict a main effect, such that participants in the Virus condition will score higher than participants in the other two conditions.

A second one-way ANOVA will test an effect of condition on an average of attitudes towards travel bans for China and Italy. Again, we predict a main effect, such that participants in the Virus condition will score higher than participants in the other two conditions. 

Third, there will be a positive correlation between individual’s PVD score and their Xenophobia measure.

outliers.value:
Outliers: If an individual’s score for the dependent variable are more than 3 standard deviations above or below the mean, they will be winsorized 

Exclusion:
1. If answers 4 or lower in the honesty check (which directly asks participants how honest they have been) those participants will be not be used in the analysis 
2. If participants do not answer the written part of the prime, if the answer is not in coherent English, or if the participants did not follow instructions correctly in their written answer.
3. If participants do not enter in information that was provided from the prime that will be excluded

dependent.value:
Fear Based Xenophobia Scale (van der Veer et al., 2011) 1(Strongly disagree- 7 Strong Agree) A mean composite will be utilized 
1. Immigration in this country is out of control 
2. Immigration causes an increase in crimes 
3. Immigrants take jobs from people who are here already 
4. Interacting with immigrants makes me uneasy 
5. I worry that immigrants may spread unusual diseases 
6. I am afraid that in case of war or political tension immigrants will be loyal to their country of origin 
7. With increased immigration, I fear that our way of life will change for the worse 
8. I doubt that immigrants will put the interest of this country first 
9. I am afraid that our own culture will be lost with increase immigration 


Country-Specific Travel Bans 
The US government should impose a travel ban to prevent travel from the following nations from entering the US (1 Strongly Disagree- 7 Strongly Agree). 
1. China 
2. Mexico
3. Italy
4. Canada

conditions.value:
There will be three different conditions for the current experiment. 

Participants will be randomized into either Virus, Accident or Control condition (See the survey for the prime). After they read the prime, they will be asked to “Take a moment to reflect on how this information made you feel. Please briefly write about your reactions to the information.  What kind of world did the information describe? What details stood out to you most when reading? How did you feel as you read the story? You have up to two minutes for this task, after which the next arrow will appear.”  After they respond they will be asked to report 2 specific pieces of information from the prime.”

hypothesis.value:
Previous work suggests that the salience of pathogens can increase prejudice towards foreign outgroups. At the current moment (March 5th, 2020), there is an outbreak of coronavirus (COVID-19) in Asia that originated from Wuhan, China, and has spread across the world. To study how concerns about major disease outbreaks influence how people perceive outgroups, an experiment will be conducted to understand whether priming Coronavirus can lead to more negative attitudes to outgroup members. 
1. We hypothesize that participants who are reminded of the Coronavirus will be more likely to report higher levels of xenophobia compared to participants in either of the two control conditions.
2. We predict that participants reminded of the Coronavirus will report more support for travel bans pertaining to two countries closely associated with cases of the Coronavirus (China and Italy). 


We will also ask participants to respond to support for travel bans for other countries (Mexico and Canada). We do not explicitly predict effects (or lack of them) for other countries. However, if there is an experimental effect of condition as per prediction 2, we intend to conduct exploratory analyses comparing attitudes for each country. 


Based on the previous two studies, where Perceived Infectability predicted US attitudes towards the travel ban in the US, and Germ Aversion predicted Singaporean attitudes for a travel ban, we hypothesize that an overall PVD will predict participant’s attitudes xenophobia.

attributes.title: Evaluating gambling research preregistrations: Specificity & adherence
attributes.description: An evaluation of gambling study preregistrations in relation to their specificity and adherence.

summary.value:
1.	Proposed title 
-	Evaluating gambling research preregistrations: Specificity & adherence 

2.	Contributors
Robert Heirene, Ph.D., Debi A. LaPlante, Ph.D., Eric R. Louderback, Ph.D., Brittany Keen, Ph.D., Marjan Bakker, Ph.D., & Sally Gainsbury, Ph.D.

3.	Background and rationale
A preregistration is a time-stamped, immutable document that outlines the details of a proposed research study, including the study’s hypotheses, methods to be used, outcomes of interest, and data analysis plan. Study preregistration is one of several open science practices, which also include sharing data, analysis code, and research materials; the use of pre-prints and open access to articles; the promotion of study replications; and improvements to the quality of reporting (Munafò et al., 2017). Of these, preregistration is thought to be most impactful on the scientific process (Allen & Mehler, 2019) and potentially has considerable value in reducing questionable or biased research practices (Nosek et al., 2018, 2019). For example, by pre-specifying hypotheses and outcomes of interest, the ability of researchers to engage in HARKing (i.e., hypothesising after the results are known) and selective outcome reporting is reduced, or at least detectable when a published study is available. Preregistration also might reduce Researcher Degrees of Freedom (RDoF), or the many methodological choices available to researchers when they are collecting and analysing data and reporting their findings (Wicherts et al., 2016). This is important because, when researchers make these data collection and data analysis choices in an ad hoc manner, they can enter down a “garden of forking paths” (Gelman & Loken, 2013) that ultimately leads to a significantly reduced likelihood of reproducing the same outcomes in a reanalysis of the same data and difficulties in replicating the findings in new samples. The freedom to make many possible decisions during the research process (i.e., RDoF) can inflate the risk of finding false-positive results or Type-I errors (Wicherts et al., 2016), which when done is strategically known as P-hacking or asterisk hunting (Head et al., 2015). Veldkamp et al. (2018) have developed a checklist specifically for assessing the extent to which preregistrations restrict RDoF during the research process by clearly prespecifying the methods to be used.

Despite the many potential benefits of preregistration, the value of the process is limited by at least two factors: [1] the degree to which it might restrict the opportunity to use RDoF questionably through a detailed specification of the planned methods, and [2] the extent to which researchers actually follow the plan outlined in their preregistration and declare any deviations. The study proposed in this research protocol will evaluate the extent to which researchers in the field of gambling studies are effectively preregistering their research (i.e., specificity) and following the methods they specify (i.e., adherence). At this time, discussion of open science principles and practices in the gambling studies literature is limited (Blaszczynski & Gainsbury, 2019; Heirene & Gainsbury, 2020; LaPlante, 2019; Wohl et al., 2019), and there are no available assessments of gambling preregistrations’ specificity, or how well the extant preregistrations of gambling studies consider and effectively restrict opportunistic use of RDoF.

4.	Aims 
-	Evaluate the specificity of preregistrations for research on concepts related to gambling using a Researcher Degrees of Freedom (RDoF) checklist.
-	Compare RDoF checklist scores for preregistrations for research focused on concepts related to gambling with the scores for a randomly selected sample of multidisciplinary preregistrations evaluated by Veldkamp et al. (2018).
-	Examine the extent to which researchers who study topics related to gambling adhere to the methods specified in their preregistrations.

5.	Research questions 
1.	To what extent do gambling study preregistrations restrict RDoF (i.e., via clearly and comprehensively prespecifying methods)?
2.	Are researchers who study gambling-related concepts adhering to the methods outlined in their study preregistrations?
3.	How does the extent to which gambling preregistrations restrict RDoF (i.e., via clearly and comprehensively prespecifying methods) compare to that of a random selection of cross-discipline preregistrations? 

6.	Hypothesis 
As the discussion of open science principles and practices in gambling studies has been limited, we hypothesise that preregistrations of gambling studies will restrict RDoF to a lesser extent (i.e., have lower scores on the RDoF checklist items) than the multidisciplinary sample of preregistrations. No other hypotheses will be tested in the study.

Research plan
7.	Identification and selection of preregistrations 
We will search the Open Science Framework (OSF) repository (www.osf.io) for preregistrations of gambling studies by searching the terms “gambling”, “wagering”, and “betting” separately. For inclusion, the preregistration must: 
-	outline the plan for a study that is primarily focused on a gambling-related concept or concepts; 
-	be written in English; 
-	report at least one hypothesis (i.e., not represent an entirely exploratory research study);
-	not be for a review and/or meta-analytic study as these studies involve unique forms of RDoF and risks of bias that would require a separate scoring system (e.g., PRISMA-P; Moher et al., 2015);
-	not be for a clinical trial as these also involve unique forms of RDoF and risks of bias that would require a separate scoring system (e.g., CONSORT; Schulz et al., 2010); and,
-	We will include preregistrations authored by the researchers involved in the present study (i.e., this research protocol) in order to provide the most accurate and comprehensive overview of gambling study preregistrations. However, to avoid potentially biased scoring, no team member will be involved in scoring one of their own preregistrations (e.g., any preregistration authored by RH and SG will be scored by two of the remaining team members). Additionally, we will ensure that the scoring of these preregistrations is reviewed and agreed on by a researcher external to the team. 

No other inclusion or exclusion criteria will be used to select preregistrations. Although we will not be able to control the number of gambling study preregistrations available for evaluation, we have undertaken an a priori power analysis to determine how many gambling and multidisciplinary study preregistrations would be required to achieve 0.80 power (i.e., 1 - , where  is the Type-II error probability) assuming a medium effect size. Using G*Power V3.1.9.4, we calculated that for a Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test with power of 0.80, an effect size of 0.5 (d), and alpha (i.e., where  is the Type-I error probability) at 0.05, 53 preregistrations per group (n = 106 overall; 53 gambling and 53 multidisciplinary studies) would be required. This is identical to the outcome of the power analysis undertaken by Veldkamp et al. (2018), who included 53 preregistrations in each of their two groups. Considering the outcomes of our power analysis, we will include a maximum of 60 gambling study preregistrations due to resource limitations; however, there may be fewer than 60 preregistrations that meet our inclusion criteria. There will be no minimum restriction on the number of registrations included. Gambling study preregistrations will be initially identified on one date during April 2020. If fewer than 60 preregistrations meeting eligibility criteria are identified on this date, an updated search using the same terms and selection criteria will be carried out mid-way through the coding process (estimated date: May 2020). No additional preregistrations will be included after this second round of identification and selection, even if fewer than 60 relevant preregistrations have been identified. If more than 60 preregistrations are identified on either occasion that meet our eligibility criteria then the details of them all (i.e., name, link, date) will be put into a .csv file and ordered using a random number generator in R (see R script on OSF under the “scripts” tab: “Randomly_select_registrations.R”). Following this process, we will select the first 60 preregistrations.

One member of the research team (BK) will undertake the search and selection process. A second team member (RH) will check 10% of included registrations and 10% of excluded registrations for the accuracy of the selection process. If any inaccuracies are observed (e.g., an excluded registration meets the eligibility criteria for inclusion), the second team member (RH) will screen all included and excluded registrations for accuracy. In the report of findings, we will present a flowchart outlining the search and selection processes.

8.  Scoring of preregistration specificity 
To evaluate the quality and specificity of the preregistrations identified, we will use the RDoF checklist developed by Wicherts et al. (2016) and later converted to a scoring protocol for preregistration evaluation by Veldkamp et al. (2018). This scoring protocol contains 22 questions relating to 29 potential areas where researchers could use their RDoF opportunistically during the research processes (e.g., during decisions relating to sample size, participant eligibility criteria, or randomisation).  The protocol allows readers to score the extent to which a clearly specified plan in the preregistration  restricted each area. Coders assign a “restriction score” between 0 and 3 to each of the protocol questions:

0 = not specified—opportunistic use of RDoF not restricted at all.
1 = some specification but lacking details— opportunistic use of RDoF is restricted to some extent.
2 = detailed specification—opportunistic use of RDoF is completely restricted, but no explicit statement confirming that authors will not deviate from this plan by adding additional methods/processes.
3 = detailed specification and statement that authors will not deviate from their plan by adding additional methods/processes (e.g., in a recent preregistration written by two of the present authors, we outlined the reasons why a participant’s data may be excluded from analyses before stating: “Individuals will not be excluded from analyses for reasons other than those stated here.” [osf.io/6dpkw])—opportunistic use of RDoF is completely restricted.
N.A. = RDoF item not relevant to preregistration. 

Some questions have dependencies. For example, question 2 in the scoring protocol is: “Does the text explicitly exclude the possibility that at least one other variable (e.g., a covariate) is included in the analysis testing the hypothesis reported in the confirmatory analysis section?”. This question corresponds to RDoF D2 (“measuring additional variables that can lead to be selected as covariates, independent variables, mediators, or moderators”) and RDoF A10 (“choosing to include different measured variables as covariates, independent variables, mediators, or moderators”) in Witcherts et al.’s (2016) checklist. As a result, the same restriction score will be given to both D2 and A10 as a result of scoring question 2 in the protocol. Overall, although there are only 22 questions, restriction scores for 29 RDoFs are produced via Veldcamp et al.’s (2018) scoring protocol.

Two researchers will independently code each preregistration according to the scoring protocol, convening to discuss any inconsistencies in restriction scores. Where any disagreements cannot be resolved by the two coders, a third member of the research team will be consulted.

Given concerns regarding many gambling researchers’ conflicts of interest (Cassidy, 2014), we also will score gambling study preregistrations on whether relevant disclosures are reported. We will use the International Gambling Studies (IGS) three-factor disclosure framework to structure our assessment. IGS’ framework requires authors to disclose [1] funding sources for the work, [2] any competing interests, and [3] any constraints on publishing the findings made by funders or stakeholders. We will score the sample of gambling preregistrations identified in this study on each of the three factors as either 0 (no mention) or 3 (relevant disclosure reported). We anticipate low scores on these items because preregistration recommendations typically have not included disclosing conflicts of interests in advance of undertaking studies. 

Restriction scores will not be computed using any method other than stated in this section. 

9.	Scoring of preregistration adherence
After scoring the preregistrations’ specificity using the RDoF checklist, we will search for all pre-prints and peer-reviewed publications reporting results from the scored studies. We do not expect all preregistrations to have an associated pre-print/publication; although, we would anticipate that all those first registered more than two years prior to our search date will have findings reported somewhere unless the timeline specified in the preregistration suggests that this would not be possible. We will report the number of preregistrations with no associated report of findings registered more than two years prior to our search date. 
Using each of the items in the RDoF checklist, we will evaluate the extent to which the methods reported are consistent with those specified in the authors’ preregistration (if both a pre-print and peer-reviewed publication of findings are available, the latter will be selected for evaluation). Each RDoF item (e.g., hypotheses, primary outcome, etc.) will be assigned a “deviation score” between 0 and 3: 
0 = consistent with preregistration—no deviation. 
1 = deviation from preregistration made and declared by the authors and a justification for change is provided.
2 = deviation from preregistration made and declared, but no justification for deviation is provided. 
3 = deviation made and not declared or justified by the authors 
N.A. = not relevant/unable to determine. 
Note, although we have distinguished between no deviation (score of 0) and deviation from preregistration that is declared justified (score of 1) to provide the most informative scoring system, we do not necessarily the view the latter as being “worse” or bad practice as we recognise the need for flexibility where appropriate and difficulties researchers can face in predicting all contingencies. 

We will accept explicit reference to the preregistration methods as confirmation that the prespecified methods were adhered to. That is, if a researcher states something analogous to “We followed the methods specified in our preregistration for data handling and cleaning”, items will be scored as 0 unless any deviations in the pre-print or peer-reviewed publication are observed by the research team. 

We will score items related to disclosures for adherence. That is, we will compare the disclosures stated in the preregistration (if any) with the disclosures stated in the report of findings and score consistency using the same 0-3 scoring system used for RDoF items. 

10.	Comparing gambling and multidisciplinary preregistrations
Restriction scores for gambling preregistrations will be compared with those for the cross-discipline preregistrations scored by Veldkamp et al. (2018). Vedlkamp and colleagues compared the extent to which RDoF was restricted by two forms of preregistration—the Open-Ended Registration format and the Preregistration Challenge format—randomly selecting a sample of 53 preregistrations from each. We will compare our sample with the 53 Preregistration Challenge sample. We conducted a brief preliminary scoping exercise to explore the preregistration formats used by gambling researchers on OSF and structured formats appeared to be used more commonly than the open-ended format. Most frequently observed were the Standard OSF format (formerly the Preregistration Challenge format) and the AsPredicted template. Based on these preliminary observations, it appears more appropriate to compare gambling preregistrations with Velkamp and colleagues’ Preregistration Challenge sample. 

11.	Scoring guide and framework
We have created a scoring guide to assist researchers with the scoring of preregistrations. This scoring guide outlines the original 29-item RDoF checklist developed by Wicherts et al. (2016), the corresponding preregistration scoring items developed by Veldkamp et al. (2018), and comments on scoring each item made by the research team. The scoring guide file is available on this project’s OSF page: “scoring_guide.xlsx”.

We have also developed a scoring framework for recording the scoring of preregistrations according to each RDoF. The framework contains space to record adherence to preregistrations according to each item in the RDoF checklist. The scoring framework file is available on OSF: “scoring_framework.xlsx”. Two identical scoring frameworks will be used by the two coders to avoid one coder’s scores influencing the other’s judgments. Prior to undertaking inter-coder consistency and confirmatory analyses, the datasets will be screened for missing scores. If missing scores are identified, the coder responsible will address accordingly. The final decided scores will be included in a separate data frame used for analyses.

12.	Trial coding and inter-coder consistency
Before commencing the study, we will select 10% of the gambling study preregistrations with associated pre-prints/publications from the sample returned by our search process (section 7 above) to pilot test the scoring procedures outlined in sections 8 and 9 (these will be included in the final set). Two coders will independently score the specificity of preregistrations (restriction scores) and pre-prints/publications adherence to them (deviation scores). The level of inter-coder reliability achieved for both scores will be quantified separately using Krippendorff’s alpha (). If the reliability coefficient for either or both is less than 0.7 (Krippendorff, 2004), we will review the scoring procedures and undertake another round of trial scoring (for either or both of the scoring procedures for which reliability was unsatisfactory), repeating the process until a satisfactory level of reliability is achieved (i.e.,  ≥ 0.7).  We will use the R package “irr” (Gamer & Lemon, 2012) to calculate . An analysis script for the planned inter-coder reliability analysis can be found on this project’s OSF page with the file name “Inter-coder_consistency.R”.

13.	Data management and analysis software
Data will be stored in .xlsx or .omv files in jamovi (The jamovi Project, 2019). All analyses will be conducted using the statistical analysis software R Studio V 1.2.1578 (R Studio Team, 2019) or its associated graphical user-interface jamovi. As well as base R functions, we will use the “tidyverse”, “yarrr” and “reshape” packages in RStudio for data management and some analyses, as well as the “mice” package for checking for the presence of “N.A.” scores before implementing a data imputation procedure and the “irr” package for intercoder consistency analyses. No other statistical analysis software will be used. 

14.	Analysis plan
We will calculate the arithmetic mean (plus standard deviation) and median restriction scores for each RDoF item and overall (i.e., mean scores on all items will be summed for each group of preregistrations and divided by the total number of items [n = 29]). When computing overall scores, we will not weight items according to any criteria (e.g., risk of bias, importance to the research study), although as stated in section 8, there are some dependencies between items and therefore scores to some questions will carry more weight. Restriction scores will not be summarised in any other way. Restriction scores will be tabulated for ease of comparison—see Example Table 1 in the Appendix (only included in PDF version of preregistered protocol). 

We will use one-tailed non-parametric Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney analyses to test the hypothesis that preregistrations of gambling studies will restrict RDoF to a lesser extent (i.e., have lower restriction scores) than the multidisciplinary sample of preregistrations. The Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney tests will compare differences in restriction scores between gambling preregistrations and the random sample (n = 53) of multidisciplinary preregistrations selected by Veldkamp et al. (2018). For restriction scores scored as “N.A.”, Veldkamp et al. used a two-way imputation procedure based on corresponding row and column means before the restriction scores between the two groups of preregistrations were compared. Before conducting our confirmatory analyses, we will employ the same procedure for gambling preregistrations that are given N.A. scores and the resulting imputed data will be compared with the imputed data for Veldkamp and colleagues’ 53 multidiscipline preregistrations. Descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, median) will be calculated on the non-imputed dataset, with N.A. values excluded. No other method of dealing with missing data points will be used. 

Non-parametric tests will be used to test our hypothesis as Veldkamp and colleagues (2018) observed that restriction scores were more likely to be in the lower range (0–1) than upper range (2–3) in their sample of registrations and therefore scores were positively skewed. We will compare differences between the two groups of registrations on all individual items scores and the overall scores, resulting in a total of 30 Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney tests (29 individual item restriction scores and 1 overall restriction score). Restriction scores for conflicts of interest disclosures (which will not be included when calculating the overall restriction score) were not computed by Veldkamp et al. (2018) and therefore cannot be compared between the two groups. To minimise the false discovery rate (FDR), we will use the Benjamini-Hochberg correction technique (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) with the FDR set at 5%. This process will involve comparing each p value returned from confirmatory analyses to its Benjamini-Hochberg “critical value”, which is calculated as: (i/m)Q, where i = the rank of the p value (ordered from smallest to largest), m = the total number of tests undertaken,  and Q = the FDR we select (i.e., .05). In Example Table 2 in the Appendix (only included in PDF version of preregistered protocol) we have included the Benjamini-Hochberg critical values required for 30 tests (the R script used to calculate these critical values can be found on this project’s Open Science Framework page, file name: “Benjamini-Hochberg_critical_value_calculations.R”). In any follow-up exploratory analyses, will use p < 0.05 as the inference criterion for determining statistical significance. No other inference criteria will be used.

We will not exclude datapoints (i.e., restriction scores) from confirmatory analyses for any reason other than stated here. No additional covariates or variables will be included in the confirmatory analyses and no outcome other than restriction scores will be the focus of confirmatory testing. We will not transform the data in any way and will not check that the data meets any specific statistical assumptions (e.g., by investigating distribution of scores).

We also will calculate the unweighted arithmetic mean (plus standard deviation) and median deviation scores for each RDoF item and overall (i.e., mean deviation scores on all items will be summed and divided by the total number of items [n = 29]). We also will tabulate these and provide qualitative descriptions of the deviations that explain the type and extent of deviation, where relevant (e.g., “Item 2 (direction of hypothesis): Two papers reported using a one-tailed analysis to test their hypothesis, despite the authors reporting a bidirectional hypothesis in their preregistration”). We also will calculate the total number of undisclosed deviations (i.e., deviation score 2) for each pre-print/publication and overall. Deviation scores will only be summarised using the descriptive statistics stated here and will not be analysed using inferential statistical tests. No data points (i.e., individual deviation scores) will be omitted from descriptive summaries of the data for any reason. 

The analysis scripts for calculating descriptive statistics and for the statistical comparisons of restriction scores are shared on OSF under the “scripts” component.


 
Disclosures

registration_responses.summary:
1.	Proposed title 
-	Evaluating gambling research preregistrations: Specificity & adherence 

2.	Contributors
Robert Heirene, Ph.D., Debi A. LaPlante, Ph.D., Eric R. Louderback, Ph.D., Brittany Keen, Ph.D., Marjan Bakker, Ph.D., & Sally Gainsbury, Ph.D.

3.	Background and rationale
A preregistration is a time-stamped, immutable document that outlines the details of a proposed research study, including the study’s hypotheses, methods to be used, outcomes of interest, and data analysis plan. Study preregistration is one of several open science practices, which also include sharing data, analysis code, and research materials; the use of pre-prints and open access to articles; the promotion of study replications; and improvements to the quality of reporting (Munafò et al., 2017). Of these, preregistration is thought to be most impactful on the scientific process (Allen & Mehler, 2019) and potentially has considerable value in reducing questionable or biased research practices (Nosek et al., 2018, 2019). For example, by pre-specifying hypotheses and outcomes of interest, the ability of researchers to engage in HARKing (i.e., hypothesising after the results are known) and selective outcome reporting is reduced, or at least detectable when a published study is available. Preregistration also might reduce Researcher Degrees of Freedom (RDoF), or the many methodological choices available to researchers when they are collecting and analysing data and reporting their findings (Wicherts et al., 2016). This is important because, when researchers make these data collection and data analysis choices in an ad hoc manner, they can enter down a “garden of forking paths” (Gelman & Loken, 2013) that ultimately leads to a significantly reduced likelihood of reproducing the same outcomes in a reanalysis of the same data and difficulties in replicating the findings in new samples. The freedom to make many possible decisions during the research process (i.e., RDoF) can inflate the risk of finding false-positive results or Type-I errors (Wicherts et al., 2016), which when done is strategically known as P-hacking or asterisk hunting (Head et al., 2015). Veldkamp et al. (2018) have developed a checklist specifically for assessing the extent to which preregistrations restrict RDoF during the research process by clearly prespecifying the methods to be used.

Despite the many potential benefits of preregistration, the value of the process is limited by at least two factors: [1] the degree to which it might restrict the opportunity to use RDoF questionably through a detailed specification of the planned methods, and [2] the extent to which researchers actually follow the plan outlined in their preregistration and declare any deviations. The study proposed in this research protocol will evaluate the extent to which researchers in the field of gambling studies are effectively preregistering their research (i.e., specificity) and following the methods they specify (i.e., adherence). At this time, discussion of open science principles and practices in the gambling studies literature is limited (Blaszczynski & Gainsbury, 2019; Heirene & Gainsbury, 2020; LaPlante, 2019; Wohl et al., 2019), and there are no available assessments of gambling preregistrations’ specificity, or how well the extant preregistrations of gambling studies consider and effectively restrict opportunistic use of RDoF.

4.	Aims 
-	Evaluate the specificity of preregistrations for research on concepts related to gambling using a Researcher Degrees of Freedom (RDoF) checklist.
-	Compare RDoF checklist scores for preregistrations for research focused on concepts related to gambling with the scores for a randomly selected sample of multidisciplinary preregistrations evaluated by Veldkamp et al. (2018).
-	Examine the extent to which researchers who study topics related to gambling adhere to the methods specified in their preregistrations.

5.	Research questions 
1.	To what extent do gambling study preregistrations restrict RDoF (i.e., via clearly and comprehensively prespecifying methods)?
2.	Are researchers who study gambling-related concepts adhering to the methods outlined in their study preregistrations?
3.	How does the extent to which gambling preregistrations restrict RDoF (i.e., via clearly and comprehensively prespecifying methods) compare to that of a random selection of cross-discipline preregistrations? 

6.	Hypothesis 
As the discussion of open science principles and practices in gambling studies has been limited, we hypothesise that preregistrations of gambling studies will restrict RDoF to a lesser extent (i.e., have lower scores on the RDoF checklist items) than the multidisciplinary sample of preregistrations. No other hypotheses will be tested in the study.

Research plan
7.	Identification and selection of preregistrations 
We will search the Open Science Framework (OSF) repository (www.osf.io) for preregistrations of gambling studies by searching the terms “gambling”, “wagering”, and “betting” separately. For inclusion, the preregistration must: 
-	outline the plan for a study that is primarily focused on a gambling-related concept or concepts; 
-	be written in English; 
-	report at least one hypothesis (i.e., not represent an entirely exploratory research study);
-	not be for a review and/or meta-analytic study as these studies involve unique forms of RDoF and risks of bias that would require a separate scoring system (e.g., PRISMA-P; Moher et al., 2015);
-	not be for a clinical trial as these also involve unique forms of RDoF and risks of bias that would require a separate scoring system (e.g., CONSORT; Schulz et al., 2010); and,
-	We will include preregistrations authored by the researchers involved in the present study (i.e., this research protocol) in order to provide the most accurate and comprehensive overview of gambling study preregistrations. However, to avoid potentially biased scoring, no team member will be involved in scoring one of their own preregistrations (e.g., any preregistration authored by RH and SG will be scored by two of the remaining team members). Additionally, we will ensure that the scoring of these preregistrations is reviewed and agreed on by a researcher external to the team. 

No other inclusion or exclusion criteria will be used to select preregistrations. Although we will not be able to control the number of gambling study preregistrations available for evaluation, we have undertaken an a priori power analysis to determine how many gambling and multidisciplinary study preregistrations would be required to achieve 0.80 power (i.e., 1 - , where  is the Type-II error probability) assuming a medium effect size. Using G*Power V3.1.9.4, we calculated that for a Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test with power of 0.80, an effect size of 0.5 (d), and alpha (i.e., where  is the Type-I error probability) at 0.05, 53 preregistrations per group (n = 106 overall; 53 gambling and 53 multidisciplinary studies) would be required. This is identical to the outcome of the power analysis undertaken by Veldkamp et al. (2018), who included 53 preregistrations in each of their two groups. Considering the outcomes of our power analysis, we will include a maximum of 60 gambling study preregistrations due to resource limitations; however, there may be fewer than 60 preregistrations that meet our inclusion criteria. There will be no minimum restriction on the number of registrations included. Gambling study preregistrations will be initially identified on one date during April 2020. If fewer than 60 preregistrations meeting eligibility criteria are identified on this date, an updated search using the same terms and selection criteria will be carried out mid-way through the coding process (estimated date: May 2020). No additional preregistrations will be included after this second round of identification and selection, even if fewer than 60 relevant preregistrations have been identified. If more than 60 preregistrations are identified on either occasion that meet our eligibility criteria then the details of them all (i.e., name, link, date) will be put into a .csv file and ordered using a random number generator in R (see R script on OSF under the “scripts” tab: “Randomly_select_registrations.R”). Following this process, we will select the first 60 preregistrations.

One member of the research team (BK) will undertake the search and selection process. A second team member (RH) will check 10% of included registrations and 10% of excluded registrations for the accuracy of the selection process. If any inaccuracies are observed (e.g., an excluded registration meets the eligibility criteria for inclusion), the second team member (RH) will screen all included and excluded registrations for accuracy. In the report of findings, we will present a flowchart outlining the search and selection processes.

8.  Scoring of preregistration specificity 
To evaluate the quality and specificity of the preregistrations identified, we will use the RDoF checklist developed by Wicherts et al. (2016) and later converted to a scoring protocol for preregistration evaluation by Veldkamp et al. (2018). This scoring protocol contains 22 questions relating to 29 potential areas where researchers could use their RDoF opportunistically during the research processes (e.g., during decisions relating to sample size, participant eligibility criteria, or randomisation).  The protocol allows readers to score the extent to which a clearly specified plan in the preregistration  restricted each area. Coders assign a “restriction score” between 0 and 3 to each of the protocol questions:

0 = not specified—opportunistic use of RDoF not restricted at all.
1 = some specification but lacking details— opportunistic use of RDoF is restricted to some extent.
2 = detailed specification—opportunistic use of RDoF is completely restricted, but no explicit statement confirming that authors will not deviate from this plan by adding additional methods/processes.
3 = detailed specification and statement that authors will not deviate from their plan by adding additional methods/processes (e.g., in a recent preregistration written by two of the present authors, we outlined the reasons why a participant’s data may be excluded from analyses before stating: “Individuals will not be excluded from analyses for reasons other than those stated here.” [osf.io/6dpkw])—opportunistic use of RDoF is completely restricted.
N.A. = RDoF item not relevant to preregistration. 

Some questions have dependencies. For example, question 2 in the scoring protocol is: “Does the text explicitly exclude the possibility that at least one other variable (e.g., a covariate) is included in the analysis testing the hypothesis reported in the confirmatory analysis section?”. This question corresponds to RDoF D2 (“measuring additional variables that can lead to be selected as covariates, independent variables, mediators, or moderators”) and RDoF A10 (“choosing to include different measured variables as covariates, independent variables, mediators, or moderators”) in Witcherts et al.’s (2016) checklist. As a result, the same restriction score will be given to both D2 and A10 as a result of scoring question 2 in the protocol. Overall, although there are only 22 questions, restriction scores for 29 RDoFs are produced via Veldcamp et al.’s (2018) scoring protocol.

Two researchers will independently code each preregistration according to the scoring protocol, convening to discuss any inconsistencies in restriction scores. Where any disagreements cannot be resolved by the two coders, a third member of the research team will be consulted.

Given concerns regarding many gambling researchers’ conflicts of interest (Cassidy, 2014), we also will score gambling study preregistrations on whether relevant disclosures are reported. We will use the International Gambling Studies (IGS) three-factor disclosure framework to structure our assessment. IGS’ framework requires authors to disclose [1] funding sources for the work, [2] any competing interests, and [3] any constraints on publishing the findings made by funders or stakeholders. We will score the sample of gambling preregistrations identified in this study on each of the three factors as either 0 (no mention) or 3 (relevant disclosure reported). We anticipate low scores on these items because preregistration recommendations typically have not included disclosing conflicts of interests in advance of undertaking studies. 

Restriction scores will not be computed using any method other than stated in this section. 

9.	Scoring of preregistration adherence
After scoring the preregistrations’ specificity using the RDoF checklist, we will search for all pre-prints and peer-reviewed publications reporting results from the scored studies. We do not expect all preregistrations to have an associated pre-print/publication; although, we would anticipate that all those first registered more than two years prior to our search date will have findings reported somewhere unless the timeline specified in the preregistration suggests that this would not be possible. We will report the number of preregistrations with no associated report of findings registered more than two years prior to our search date. 
Using each of the items in the RDoF checklist, we will evaluate the extent to which the methods reported are consistent with those specified in the authors’ preregistration (if both a pre-print and peer-reviewed publication of findings are available, the latter will be selected for evaluation). Each RDoF item (e.g., hypotheses, primary outcome, etc.) will be assigned a “deviation score” between 0 and 3: 
0 = consistent with preregistration—no deviation. 
1 = deviation from preregistration made and declared by the authors and a justification for change is provided.
2 = deviation from preregistration made and declared, but no justification for deviation is provided. 
3 = deviation made and not declared or justified by the authors 
N.A. = not relevant/unable to determine. 
Note, although we have distinguished between no deviation (score of 0) and deviation from preregistration that is declared justified (score of 1) to provide the most informative scoring system, we do not necessarily the view the latter as being “worse” or bad practice as we recognise the need for flexibility where appropriate and difficulties researchers can face in predicting all contingencies. 

We will accept explicit reference to the preregistration methods as confirmation that the prespecified methods were adhered to. That is, if a researcher states something analogous to “We followed the methods specified in our preregistration for data handling and cleaning”, items will be scored as 0 unless any deviations in the pre-print or peer-reviewed publication are observed by the research team. 

We will score items related to disclosures for adherence. That is, we will compare the disclosures stated in the preregistration (if any) with the disclosures stated in the report of findings and score consistency using the same 0-3 scoring system used for RDoF items. 

10.	Comparing gambling and multidisciplinary preregistrations
Restriction scores for gambling preregistrations will be compared with those for the cross-discipline preregistrations scored by Veldkamp et al. (2018). Vedlkamp and colleagues compared the extent to which RDoF was restricted by two forms of preregistration—the Open-Ended Registration format and the Preregistration Challenge format—randomly selecting a sample of 53 preregistrations from each. We will compare our sample with the 53 Preregistration Challenge sample. We conducted a brief preliminary scoping exercise to explore the preregistration formats used by gambling researchers on OSF and structured formats appeared to be used more commonly than the open-ended format. Most frequently observed were the Standard OSF format (formerly the Preregistration Challenge format) and the AsPredicted template. Based on these preliminary observations, it appears more appropriate to compare gambling preregistrations with Velkamp and colleagues’ Preregistration Challenge sample. 

11.	Scoring guide and framework
We have created a scoring guide to assist researchers with the scoring of preregistrations. This scoring guide outlines the original 29-item RDoF checklist developed by Wicherts et al. (2016), the corresponding preregistration scoring items developed by Veldkamp et al. (2018), and comments on scoring each item made by the research team. The scoring guide file is available on this project’s OSF page: “scoring_guide.xlsx”.

We have also developed a scoring framework for recording the scoring of preregistrations according to each RDoF. The framework contains space to record adherence to preregistrations according to each item in the RDoF checklist. The scoring framework file is available on OSF: “scoring_framework.xlsx”. Two identical scoring frameworks will be used by the two coders to avoid one coder’s scores influencing the other’s judgments. Prior to undertaking inter-coder consistency and confirmatory analyses, the datasets will be screened for missing scores. If missing scores are identified, the coder responsible will address accordingly. The final decided scores will be included in a separate data frame used for analyses.

12.	Trial coding and inter-coder consistency
Before commencing the study, we will select 10% of the gambling study preregistrations with associated pre-prints/publications from the sample returned by our search process (section 7 above) to pilot test the scoring procedures outlined in sections 8 and 9 (these will be included in the final set). Two coders will independently score the specificity of preregistrations (restriction scores) and pre-prints/publications adherence to them (deviation scores). The level of inter-coder reliability achieved for both scores will be quantified separately using Krippendorff’s alpha (). If the reliability coefficient for either or both is less than 0.7 (Krippendorff, 2004), we will review the scoring procedures and undertake another round of trial scoring (for either or both of the scoring procedures for which reliability was unsatisfactory), repeating the process until a satisfactory level of reliability is achieved (i.e.,  ≥ 0.7).  We will use the R package “irr” (Gamer & Lemon, 2012) to calculate . An analysis script for the planned inter-coder reliability analysis can be found on this project’s OSF page with the file name “Inter-coder_consistency.R”.

13.	Data management and analysis software
Data will be stored in .xlsx or .omv files in jamovi (The jamovi Project, 2019). All analyses will be conducted using the statistical analysis software R Studio V 1.2.1578 (R Studio Team, 2019) or its associated graphical user-interface jamovi. As well as base R functions, we will use the “tidyverse”, “yarrr” and “reshape” packages in RStudio for data management and some analyses, as well as the “mice” package for checking for the presence of “N.A.” scores before implementing a data imputation procedure and the “irr” package for intercoder consistency analyses. No other statistical analysis software will be used. 

14.	Analysis plan
We will calculate the arithmetic mean (plus standard deviation) and median restriction scores for each RDoF item and overall (i.e., mean scores on all items will be summed for each group of preregistrations and divided by the total number of items [n = 29]). When computing overall scores, we will not weight items according to any criteria (e.g., risk of bias, importance to the research study), although as stated in section 8, there are some dependencies between items and therefore scores to some questions will carry more weight. Restriction scores will not be summarised in any other way. Restriction scores will be tabulated for ease of comparison—see Example Table 1 in the Appendix (only included in PDF version of preregistered protocol). 

We will use one-tailed non-parametric Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney analyses to test the hypothesis that preregistrations of gambling studies will restrict RDoF to a lesser extent (i.e., have lower restriction scores) than the multidisciplinary sample of preregistrations. The Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney tests will compare differences in restriction scores between gambling preregistrations and the random sample (n = 53) of multidisciplinary preregistrations selected by Veldkamp et al. (2018). For restriction scores scored as “N.A.”, Veldkamp et al. used a two-way imputation procedure based on corresponding row and column means before the restriction scores between the two groups of preregistrations were compared. Before conducting our confirmatory analyses, we will employ the same procedure for gambling preregistrations that are given N.A. scores and the resulting imputed data will be compared with the imputed data for Veldkamp and colleagues’ 53 multidiscipline preregistrations. Descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, median) will be calculated on the non-imputed dataset, with N.A. values excluded. No other method of dealing with missing data points will be used. 

Non-parametric tests will be used to test our hypothesis as Veldkamp and colleagues (2018) observed that restriction scores were more likely to be in the lower range (0–1) than upper range (2–3) in their sample of registrations and therefore scores were positively skewed. We will compare differences between the two groups of registrations on all individual items scores and the overall scores, resulting in a total of 30 Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney tests (29 individual item restriction scores and 1 overall restriction score). Restriction scores for conflicts of interest disclosures (which will not be included when calculating the overall restriction score) were not computed by Veldkamp et al. (2018) and therefore cannot be compared between the two groups. To minimise the false discovery rate (FDR), we will use the Benjamini-Hochberg correction technique (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) with the FDR set at 5%. This process will involve comparing each p value returned from confirmatory analyses to its Benjamini-Hochberg “critical value”, which is calculated as: (i/m)Q, where i = the rank of the p value (ordered from smallest to largest), m = the total number of tests undertaken,  and Q = the FDR we select (i.e., .05). In Example Table 2 in the Appendix (only included in PDF version of preregistered protocol) we have included the Benjamini-Hochberg critical values required for 30 tests (the R script used to calculate these critical values can be found on this project’s Open Science Framework page, file name: “Benjamini-Hochberg_critical_value_calculations.R”). In any follow-up exploratory analyses, will use p < 0.05 as the inference criterion for determining statistical significance. No other inference criteria will be used.

We will not exclude datapoints (i.e., restriction scores) from confirmatory analyses for any reason other than stated here. No additional covariates or variables will be included in the confirmatory analyses and no outcome other than restriction scores will be the focus of confirmatory testing. We will not transform the data in any way and will not check that the data meets any specific statistical assumptions (e.g., by investigating distribution of scores).

We also will calculate the unweighted arithmetic mean (plus standard deviation) and median deviation scores for each RDoF item and overall (i.e., mean deviation scores on all items will be summed and divided by the total number of items [n = 29]). We also will tabulate these and provide qualitative descriptions of the deviations that explain the type and extent of deviation, where relevant (e.g., “Item 2 (direction of hypothesis): Two papers reported using a one-tailed analysis to test their hypothesis, despite the authors reporting a bidirectional hypothesis in their preregistration”). We also will calculate the total number of undisclosed deviations (i.e., deviation score 2) for each pre-print/publication and overall. Deviation scores will only be summarised using the descriptive statistics stated here and will not be analysed using inferential statistical tests. No data points (i.e., individual deviation scores) will be omitted from descriptive summaries of the data for any reason. 

The analysis scripts for calculating descriptive statistics and for the statistical comparisons of restriction scores are shared on OSF under the “scripts” component.

attributes.title: Longitudinal study on behavioral, psychological, socio-economic effects induced by the exposure to CoViD-19, by government measures, and by communication strategies in three countries: Italy, Spain, and United Kingdom
attributes.description:
We will conduct a longitudinal study (with four waves) in three countries to measure short run and long run behavioral change induced by the exposure to CoViD19 and response to government strategy and communication. 
The study includes a baseline, two interventions, and a follow up. In week two and three, we will conduct experiments using priming to test: (a) if trauma and shock induce changes in preferences and cognitive performance; (b) if differences in terms of epistemic uncertainty, non value consensus, and conflict of interests affect approval of different communications strategies by the government (expert based, deliberative, and negotiation). In week four, we assess approval of contested claims that (1) the economic costs has not been taken into consideration, (2) the communication by authorities is too paternalistic, controlling for social desirability bias. Health and economic consequences will be monitored across the four waves.

q1.value: Francesco Bogliacino, Francisco Lupiañez Villanueva, cristiano codagnone, Rafael Alberto Charris, Camilo Ernesto Gómez Cangrejo, F. Folkvord (Frans), Felipe Montealegre, Giuseppe Veltri, giovanni liva, gerda reith

q2.value:
H1: Trauma induces pro sociality, risk aversion, higher temporal discount and lower cognitive performance
H2: Exposure to shocks induces pro sociality, risk aversion, higher temporal discount and lower cognitive performance
H3: Expert based communication is preferred under value consensus, low epistemic uncertainty, diffused interests
H4: Deliberative is preferred under high epistemic uncertainty
H5: Negotiated is preferred under conflict of interests and value conflict
H6: There is significant fear of economic consequences of the policy response, and there is significant frustration with expert based communication strategy
H7: There will be log run behavioral change in the following direction: (positive) more cultural consumption, higher saving rate, (negative) lower earnings, less relational social capital, more risky health behavior in non CoViD19 related domains

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We will sample 1000 participants (random sampling) per country, in three countries, and follow them for four weeks. 
In week one, we profile the respondents first in terms of CoViD19 exposure and potential risk, and second in terms of fragility to shocks (economic fragility, excess responsibilities etc.). In week two, we prime participants to detect if exposure to CoViD19 trauma and shock (two different priming) can affect cognitive function, risk and time preferences, altruism, trust, and reciprocity. In week three, we prime the participants towards the presence of epistemic uncertainty, value conflict related to privacy, or conflict of interests related with distributional consequences, to see how they respond to three policies that have been implemented or proposed (lockdown, antigens testing and release, and use of tracking to monitor exposure to virus) and how the government communicate to motivate these measures. With respect to the communication strategies, we evaluate expert based communication, deliberative consultation, and negotiated conflict among different positions. Finally, in week four, we evaluate the extent of the critiques towards current policy response and communication strategy, controlling for Social Desirability Bias. Across the four waves, we will monitor evolution of health and economic consequences.

q7.value:
In week two, we will have three experimental conditions. In each condition, participants will answer a question before completing the questionnaire. Below we present the conditions. Assignment: 300 persons will receive the trauma priming, 300 the shock priming and 400 the control condition (200 a neutral priming and 200 a joy priming).
In week three, there will be a first between subject factor, represented by one out of six priming: high epistemic uncertainty, low epistemic uncertainty, value consensus, value conflict, diffused interests, and concentrated interests. We judge three policies and nine strategies of communicating them. Every subject is assigned to the three policies in random order but see only a justification per each. Justification is Paternalistic (P), Deliberative (D), regulated conflict (C). 		

In week four, we will conduct a list experiment: there will be random assignment between control (baseline), T1 (additional item: too much emphasis on the health problem) and T2 (additional item: communication is too paternalistic). We add a t3 with direct question to estimate social desirability bias.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Week two: assignment to priming of fear/anxiety because of the virus, priming of stress because of the potential shocks, or control condition.
Week three, there will be a first between subject factor, represented by one out of six priming: high epistemic uncertainty, low epistemic uncertainty, value consensus, value conflict, diffused interests, and concentrated interests. We judge three policies and nine strategies of communicating them. Every subject is assigned to the three policies in random order (within subject) but see only a justification per each. Order of justification is randomized (between subject).
Week four: three conditions, control (baseline), T1 (additional item: too much emphasis on the health problem), T2 (additional item: communication is too paternalistic), T3 (direct question).

1.	All waves:
a.	Behavioral response to CoViD19 [1 block]
b.	Economic consequences of CoViD19 [2 blocks]
c.	Stress and health consequences [1 block]
2.	Wave two
a.	Cognitive reflection tests
b.	Experimentally validated questions for risk aversion, time discounting, trust, positive and negative reciprocity, altruism
3.	Wave three:
a.	Approval of policy measure
b.	Persuasiveness and reliability of supporting statements 
c.	Approval of communication strategy
4.	Wave four:
a.	Approval of contested claims
b.	Optimisms/pessimism towards the future
c.	Long run behavioral change (savings, health behavior, social capital, cultural consumption)
We will create two indices via principal component analysis to define exposure to trauma and exposure to negative economic shock.

3.	Wave three:

4.	Wave four:
a.	Approval of contested claims

attributes.title: Personality Change and Environmental Concerns in GSOEP
attributes.description: The goal of this study is to examine whether changes in personality traits are related to changes in environmental concern over time.

summary.value:
Previous research has documented cross-sectional correlations between personality traits such as neuroticism (N), extraversion (E), Openness (O), agreeableness (A), and conscientiousness (C) and concerns about the environment (Brick & Lewis, 2016; Hirsh, 2010; Lee et al., 2015; Markowitz et al., 2012; Milfont & Sibley, 2012; Milfont et al., 2015). The goal of this study is to examine whether changes in these personality traits are related to changes in environmental concern over time. We will use the German Socioeconomic Panel (GSOEP), a longitudinal representative sample of 47,951 participants from Germany. 

Specific details of the research plan are in the attached document.

attributes.title: Simulating the impact of the Gran Cruzada using the Lives Saved Tool (LiST)
attributes.description:
Stunting is one of the most important child health issues globally. Guatemala has among the world’s highest prevalence of child stunting. In February 2020, the new Guatemalan government released the latest national nutrition strategy, the Gran Cruzada Nacional por la Nutrición. Like prior national nutrition strategies, the Gran Cruzada prioritizes scaling-up evidence-based, cost-effective preventative interventions delivered in the “1,000 days window.” 

Yet, the Gran Cruzada’s impact is uncertain. Nutrition interventions tend to have small effect sizes on linear growth in trials. Population coverage of interventions in Guatemala historically has been inconsistent. Finally, even with coverage improvements, it is not clear if the Gran Cruzada can reach its ambitious goals for child stunting, anemia, and other nutrition indicators.

Objective
This study aims to estimate the impact of the implementation of Guatemala’s new national nutrition policy, the Gran Cruzada. Realistic estimates of impact will be useful to nutrition policymakers and advocates in Guatemala who work to improve stunting. We plan to disseminate this work broadly in Guatemala and publish results as a peer-reviewed manuscript. 

Methods:
This study will use the Lives Saved Tool (LiST) to simulate policy implementation of the Gran Cruzada. LiST is a widely used modeling tool that uses publicly available data and intervention effect sizes to project maternal and child outcomes including stunting.

The primary outcomes of interest will be between-model changes in stunting prevalence and absolute number of stunted children ages 0-5 years. Secondary outcomes will include child mortality, maternal mortality, and anemia in women of reproductive age. Each of these outcomes corresponds with key nutrition indicators in the Gran Cruzada. We also plan to investigate the relative contribution of each intervention to these outcomes.

Overall, we plan to simulate multiple policy scenarios below. 

1. Static intervention coverage	4. Delayed implementation of Gran Cruzada
2. Continuation of historical trends	5. Scale-up to wealthiest quantile
3. Gran Cruzada scale-up by 2024	6. Aspirational coverage

Continuation of historical trends (model 2) will be based on regression models projecting future coverage expansion. The models will use population-averaged historical survey data in Guatemala and other sources recommended in LiST. We plan to fit logistic curves for coverage inputs and shift the trendline so that our projections match the most recent data available. Similar LiST forecasting method have been described previously. The key assumption of model 2 is that future coverage changes are predicted by past coverage trends.

summary.value: This registration is a summary of our plan for our study Simulating the impact of the Gran Cruzada using the Lives Saved Tool (LiST). Attached as supplemental files are our proposal and IRB letter.
