attributes.title: The effect of pathogen threat on behavioural immune system
attributes.description:
The main aim of the present project is to test, using a set of questionnaires, whether the threat caused by COVID-19 pandemic leads to an increase in perceived disgust, hygienic behaviour, xenophobia, and perceived stress as well as a decrease in pro-social behaviours.

The perception of threat will be induced by i) a priming story and ii) testing during a pandemic and after a pandemic, app. six months after the first data collection. In this way, we should be able to test interactions between these two factors, i.e. priming story and testing situation.

q1.value: Dagmar Schwambergová, Kaňková Šárka , Jitka Fialová, Jana Hlaváčová, Jan Havlíček

q2.value:
1. Individuals will show higher scores in variables related to the behavioural immune system, that is, pathogen and moral disgust (TDDS, C-DIS, BODS), hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety states, perceived stress, xenophobia, and pathogen-related memory, during the COVID-19 pandemic than during a period without acute pathogen threat, foreseen at app. six months after the first data collection, and they will do so irrespectively of the priming.

2. There will be no significant differences in sexual disgust (TDDS) between the COVID-19 pandemic period and the period without such pathogen threat.

3. We expect higher scores in pathogen and moral disgust (TDDS, C-DIS, BODS), hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety, perceived stress, and xenophobia after being exposed to the experimental condition (pathogen threat) as compared to a control priming condition. The difference will be present only during the control period but not during the period of COVID-19 pandemic.

4. We expect no changes in personality, anxiety traits, and general health status between the period during the COVID-19 pandemic and period without such pathogen threat.

5. Anxiety trait scores will positively correlate with differences in variables related to the behavioural immune system (pathogen and moral disgust, hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety state, perceived stress, and xenophobia) both during the COVID-19 pandemic and at a later testing point without such pathogen threat.

6. Scores achieved in the health status questionnaire will positively correlate with differences in variables related to the behavioural immune system (pathogen and moral disgust, hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety, perceived stress, and xenophobia) both during the COVID-19 pandemic and during the period without such pathogen threat.

7. Based on data from our pilot study, we expect that higher age will positively correlate with pathogen and moral disgust scores during the COVID-19 pandemic but not during the period without such pathogen threat.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
The study consists of two trials: the first will be carried out during the COVID-19 pandemic in the Czech Republic and the second after the acute pathogen threat had passed (app. six months after the first trial).

Participants will be provided with the same priming conditions during both trials. The priming conditions will focus on either (I) people who were infected with COVID-19, thus aiming at the threat of pathogen contamination and moral disgust (experimental condition), and (II) meltdown of a famous iceberg in Iceland, hence aiming at the threat posed by global warming (control condition).

q7.value: All participants will complete the same set of questionnaires. Priming will be randomised between participants, but all participants will be exposed to the same priming in both conditions (automatically set by Qualtrics to obtain evenly distributed experimental and control group). The order of questionnaires following the priming will be randomised to avoid a potential confounding effect caused by the sequence of questionnaires.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
The presented project will be conducted as a prospective study using a mixed within- and between-subject design. The within-subject design involves data from the same participants collected: i) during a pandemic and ii) during a period without such pathogen threat. The between-subject design involves exposure to either experimental or control priming. We will recruit participants using a snowball sampling method. Respondents will be contacted online, via Facebook sites and emails, and invited to participate anonymously in a study on disgust. Only data from individuals over 18 years of age will be included in the analyses. Participation in the study will not be reimbursed. 

Questionnaires will be completed online through the Qualtrics survey platform. They will include basic sociodemographic questions, long-term and current health issues, the Ten-Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) assessing personality characteristics and the 20-item Trait Anxiety Inventory (TAI), which explores stable anxiety traits. These questionnaires will be followed by a priming text. Randomly assigned half of respondents will be presented with a short priming story about the threat of coronavirus transmission (pathogen threat) and about violation of rules which increase the likelihood of transmission (moral disgust). The other half of respondents will be exposed to control priming focused on the threat of global warming (global threat). Priming will be followed by a set of questionnaires in a randomised order. This part will include questionnaires assessing disgust, namely the 21-item Three Domain Disgust Scale (TDDS), Culpepper Disgust Image Set (C-DIS), and 12-item Body Odor Disgust Scale (BODS), as well as questionnaires on hygienic behaviour (the 23-item Hygiene Inventory; HI-23), current anxiety (the 6-item State Anxiety Inventory, SAI), and stress (the 10-item Perceived Stress Scale; PSS). The order of questionnaires focused on social phobia (the 17-item Social Phobia Inventory; SPIN), xenophobia (9-item), and Pandemic-Related Behaviour Inventory (PRBI, with questions focused on changes in behaviour such as hygiene or the desire to meet other people in the past few weeks) will not be randomised and will be located at the end of the battery of questionnaires. SPIN and xenophobia questionnaire are not randomised due to a mistake that took place during the preparation of the whole study.

Approximately six months after the first testing (depending on the development of the current pandemic), participants who took part in the first data collection will be asked to participate in the study again. They will complete the same set of questionnaires with the same priming condition.

q11.value: The expected sample size is around 700 participants in the first trial and around 260 participants in the second trial (for details, see below).

q12.value: The number of respondents is set to 700 in the first trial (only completely answered questionnaires are counted) based on an a priori power analysis computed as the mean of effect sizes (d = 0.53) of three studies which investigated disgust in the context of xenophobia (Zakrzewska et al., 2019; d = 0.2), moral judgments after exposure to an unpleasant odour (Schnall et al., 2008; d = 0.68), and disgust in arachnophobic individuals (Mulkens, de Jong & Merckelbach, 1996; d = 0.7).  Based on our previous studies, we estimate that around 50% of respondents from the first trial will be willing to take part in the second one (i.e. they will provide email address). We further expect that around 75% of those who provide the email address will eventually complete the study, which would leave us with app. 263 respondents taking part in both trials (based on the power analysis we should have minimum sample size of 180 respondents).

q13.value: Questionnaire distribution will stop after three weeks (21 days) or after reaching 700 participants in the first trial. The second trial will be stopped after three weeks.

question.value: There will be two independent variables: i) the priming text about the pathogen threat and a global threat, and ii) the timing of questionnaire distribution, which will take place during the pandemic and during a period when the pandemic is perceived as having ended.

Measured variables will consist of the scores of TDDS, C-DIS, BODS, HI-23, SPIN, the 6-item STAI, PSS, xenophobia questionnaires, and PRBI in the context of an ongoing pandemic.

Age, health status, and TAI scores will serve as covariates.
For each questionnaire, we will do a sum of scores. In case of missing data, we will use the mean score in the corresponding domain.

To investigate the between-subject effect of the period (threat vs. non-threat) and the within-subject effect of priming and interaction of these factors, we will use repeated measure MANOVA with the following dependent variables: disgust (TDDS, C-DIS, BODS), hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety, perceived stress, xenophobia, and a memory test. 

In the follow-up analyses, we will test for possible interindividual differences including control for possible effects of sex, age, health status, and the anxiety trait on the following dependent variables: disgust (TDDS, C-DIS, BODS), hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety, perceived stress, xenophobia, and memory.

q19.value: In one-sided tests, we will consider p values < 0.05 significant.

q20.value:
Incomplete questionnaires (with over one fifth of each domain or questionnaire unanswered) will be excluded from the analyses. Additionally, we will exclude questionnaires with the same values across most items.

We will exclude respondents under 18 years of age as well as pregnant women, because during pregnancy, disgust sensitivity changes (see e.g. Żelaźniewicz & Pawłowski, 2014).

q21.value: Only at most one fifth of each domain or questionnaire can be left blank. To supplement these missing data, we will use averages of scores in the corresponding domain.

q22.value: The exploratory part of the study will consist of correlational analyses between Pandemic- Related Behaviour Inventory (PRBI) and disgust (TDDS, C-DIS, BODS), hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety, perceived stress, xenophobia and memory test. We will also test a possible relationship between socioeconomic data (such as education) and disgust (TDDS, C-DIS, BODS), hygienic behaviour, social phobia, anxiety, perceived stress, xenophobia, and memory.

q23.value:
Literature cited:

Zakrzewska, M., Olofsson, J. K., Lindholm, T., Blomkvist, A., & Liuzza, M. T. (2019). Body odor disgust sensitivity is associated with prejudice towards a fictive group of immigrants. Physiology & behavior, 201, 221-227.

Schnall, S., Haidt, J., Clore, G. L., & Jordan, A. H. (2008). Disgust as embodied moral judgment. Personality and social psychology bulletin, 34(8), 1096-1109.

Mulkens, S. A., de Jong, P. J., & Merckelbach, H. (1996). Disgust and spider phobia. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 105(3), 464.

Żelaźniewicz, A., & Pawłowski, B. (2015). Disgust in pregnancy and fetus sex—Longitudinal study. Physiology & behavior, 139, 177-181.
